title: Solving Quadratic Programs with OSQP
text: osqp package provides R bindings OSQP (Operator Splitting Quadratic Program) solver. OSQP solves convex quadratic programs form minimize12xTPx+qTxsubject tol‚â§Ax‚â§u \begin{array}{ll}   \mbox{minimize} & \frac{1}{2} x^T P x + q^T x \\   \mbox{subject } & l \leq x \leq u \end{array}  x‚ààùêënx \\mathbf{R}^n optimization variable, P‚ààùêí+nP \\mathbf{S}^n_+ positive semidefinite matrix, q‚ààùêënq \\mathbf{R}^n, ‚ààùêëm√ónA \\mathbf{R}^{m \times n}, l,u‚ààùêëml, u \\mathbf{R}^m (elements possibly equal ‚àí‚àû-\infty +‚àû+\infty). solver based Alternating Direction Method Multipliers (ADMM). Key features include: Efficient: exploits structure sparse QPs, requires single matrix factorization Robust: places requirements problem data (e.g., P need strictly positive definite); detects primal dual infeasibility Warm starting: allows reusing previous solutions speed parametric solves Polishing: optional step obtain high-accuracy solutions algorithm details see Stellato et al. (2020).

title: Solving Quadratic Programs with OSQP
text: demonstrate basic workflow small QP. First, load required packages. Define problem data. objective matrix P constraint matrix sparse (Matrix package). upper triangular part P used. corresponds : minimize12xT[4112]x+[11]Txsubject [100]‚â§[111001]x‚â§[10.70.7] \begin{array}{ll}   \mbox{minimize} & \frac{1}{2} x^T \begin{bmatrix}4 & 1\\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} x + \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}^T x \\   \mbox{subject } & \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} \leq \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1\\ 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix} x \leq  \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0.7 \\ 0.7\end{bmatrix} \end{array} Create model solve. result list containing primal solution x, dual solution y, solver information info.
code: library(osqp) library(Matrix) P <- Matrix(c(4., 1.,               1., 2.), 2, 2, sparse = TRUE) q <- c(1., 1.) A <- Matrix(c(1., 1., 0.,               1., 0., 1.), 3, 2, sparse = TRUE) l <- c(1., 0., 0.) u <- c(1., 0.7, 0.7) model <- osqp(P, q, A, l, u, pars = osqpSettings(verbose = FALSE)) result <- model@Solve() result$x #> [1] 0.3013757 0.6983957 result$y #> [1] -2.904627e+00 -1.385901e-18  2.055120e-01 result$info$status #> [1] "solved" result$info$obj_val #> [1] 1.879662

title: Solving Quadratic Programs with OSQP
text: nonzero values PP AA can updated long sparsity pattern remains . Pass new nonzero values via Px Ax. Note P must pass upper triangular nonzero values (using triu()), since OSQP stores PP upper triangular form.
code: # Create new matrices with same sparsity pattern P_new <- Matrix(c(5., 1.5,                   1.5, 1.), 2, 2, sparse = TRUE) A_new <- Matrix(c(1.2, 1.5, 0.,                   1.1, 0., 0.8), 3, 2, sparse = TRUE)  # Update only the nonzero values model@Update(Px = triu(P_new)@x, Ax = A_new@x) result <- model@Solve() result$x #> [1] 0.1813419 1.6204746

text: solving sequence related problems (e.g., parameter sweep iterative algorithm), warm starting can dramatically reduce number ADMM iterations initializing solver good starting point. can warm start just primal variables (x), just dual variables (y), . reset iterate start scratch, use ColdStart().
code:
# Solve original problem model <- osqp(P, q, A, l, u, pars = osqpSettings(verbose = FALSE,                                                    warm_starting = TRUE)) res1 <- model@Solve() cold_iters <- res1$info$iter  # Warm start with previous solution model@WarmStart(x = res1$x, y = res1$y) res2 <- model@Solve() warm_iters <- res2$info$iter  cat("Cold start iterations:", cold_iters, "
") #> Cold start iterations: 25 cat("Warm start iterations:", warm_iters, "
") #> Warm start iterations: 25 model@ColdStart() res3 <- model@Solve() cat("After cold start:", res3$info$iter, "iterations

title: Solving Quadratic Programs with OSQP
text: Lasso performs sparse linear regression adding ‚Ñì1\ell_1 penalty: minimize12‚à•Adx‚àíb‚à•22+Œ≥‚à•x‚à•1 \mbox{minimize} \quad \frac{1}{2} \| A_d x - b \|_2^2 + \gamma \| x \|_1 can reformulated QP introducing auxiliary variables yy tt: minimize12yTy+Œ≥ùüèTtsubject toy=Adx‚àíb‚àít‚â§x‚â§t \begin{array}{ll}   \mbox{minimize}   & \frac{1}{2} y^T y + \gamma \mathbf{1}^T t \\   \mbox{subject } & y = A_d x - b \\                      & -t \leq x \leq t \end{array} regularization parameter Œ≥\gamma appears linear cost qq, can update without re-factorizing KKT system. Warm starting makes sweeping Œ≥\gamma efficient.
code: set.seed(1) n <- 10   # number of features m <- 100  # number of observations  # Generate random data Ad <- Matrix(rnorm(m * n), m, n, sparse = FALSE) Ad <- as(Ad, "CsparseMatrix") x_true <- rnorm(n) * (runif(n) > 0.8) / sqrt(n) b <- as.numeric(Ad %*% x_true + 0.5 * rnorm(m))  # Auxiliary matrices In <- Diagonal(n) Im <- Diagonal(m) On <- Matrix(0, n, n, sparse = TRUE) Onm <- Matrix(0, n, m, sparse = TRUE)  # QP formulation: variables are (x, y, t) P <- bdiag(On, Im, On) q <- rep(0, 2 * n + m) A <- rbind(   cbind(Ad, -Im, Matrix(0, m, n, sparse = TRUE)),   cbind(In, Onm, -In),   cbind(In, Onm,  In) ) l <- c(b, rep(-Inf, n), rep(0, n)) u <- c(b, rep(0, n), rep(Inf, n))  # Setup model once model <- osqp(P, q, A, l, u,               pars = osqpSettings(warm_starting = TRUE, verbose = FALSE))  # Solve for a range of gamma values gammas <- seq(0.1, 2.0, length.out = 10) results <- data.frame(gamma = gammas, nnz = integer(10), obj = numeric(10))  for (i in seq_along(gammas)) {   gamma <- gammas[i]   q_new <- c(rep(0, n + m), rep(gamma, n))   model@Update(q = q_new)   res <- model@Solve()   x_hat <- res$x[1:n]   results$nnz[i] <- sum(abs(x_hat) > 1e-4)   results$obj[i] <- res$info$obj_val }  results #>        gamma nnz      obj #> 1  0.1000000  10 11.37229 #> 2  0.3111111  10 11.50198 #> 3  0.5222222  10 11.63016 #> 4  0.7333333  10 11.75222 #> 5  0.9444444   9 11.86987 #> 6  1.1555556  10 11.98151 #> 7  1.3666667  10 12.09577 #> 8  1.5777778  10 12.19795 #> 9  1.7888889   9 12.30656 #> 10 2.0000000   9 12.41062

title: Solving Quadratic Programs with OSQP
text: Mean-variance portfolio optimization allocates assets maximize risk-adjusted return: maximizeŒºTx‚àíŒ≥xTŒ£xsubject toùüèTx=1x‚â•0 \begin{array}{ll}   \mbox{maximize} & \mu^T x - \gamma \, x^T \Sigma x \\   \mbox{subject } & \mathbf{1}^T x = 1 \\                      & x \geq 0 \end{array}  x‚ààùêënx \\mathbf{R}^n portfolio, Œº\mu expected returns, Œ≥>0\gamma > 0 risk aversion, Œ£\Sigma covariance matrix. Using factor model Œ£=FFT+D\Sigma = F F^T + D (F‚ààùêën√ókF \\mathbf{R}^{n \times k}, DD diagonal), can reformulate : minimize12xTDx+12yTy‚àí12Œ≥ŒºTxsubject toy=FTxùüèTx=1x‚â•0 \begin{array}{ll}   \mbox{minimize} & \frac{1}{2} x^T D x + \frac{1}{2} y^T y - \frac{1}{2\gamma}\mu^T x \\   \mbox{subject } & y = F^T x \\                      & \mathbf{1}^T x = 1 \\                      & x \geq 0 \end{array}
code:
set.seed(42) n <- 20   # assets k <- 5    # factors gamma <- 1  # Random factor model F_mat <- Matrix(rnorm(n * k) * (runif(n * k) > 0.3), n, k, sparse = TRUE) D <- Diagonal(n, runif(n) * sqrt(k)) mu <- rnorm(n)  # QP data: variables are (x, y) P <- bdiag(D, Diagonal(k)) q <- c(-mu / (2 * gamma), rep(0, k)) A <- rbind(   cbind(t(F_mat), -Diagonal(k)),                          # y = F'x   cbind(Matrix(1, 1, n, sparse = TRUE), Matrix(0, 1, k, sparse = TRUE)),  # 1'x = 1   cbind(Diagonal(n), Matrix(0, n, k, sparse = TRUE))       # x >= 0 ) l <- c(rep(0, k), 1, rep(0, n)) u <- c(rep(0, k), 1, rep(1, n))  result <- solve_osqp(P, q, A, l, u,                      pars = osqpSettings(verbose = FALSE, polishing = TRUE)) cat("Status:", result$info$status, "
") #> Status: solved  # Portfolio weights (first n variables) weights <- result$x[1:n] cat("Invested assets:", sum(weights > 1e-4), "of", n, "
") #> Invested assets: 8 of 20 cat("Sum of weights:", round(sum(weights), 6), "
") #> Sum of weights: 1

title: Settings for OSQP ‚Äî osqpSettings
text: rho ADMM step rho rho_is_vec boolean, whether rho treated vector (per-constraint) scalar sigma ADMM step sigma max_iter maximum iterations eps_abs absolute convergence tolerance eps_rel relative convergence tolerance eps_prim_inf primal infeasibility tolerance eps_dual_inf dual infeasibility tolerance alpha relaxation parameter linsys_solver linear systems solver use, 1=OSQP_DIRECT_SOLVER (QDLDL), 2=OSQP_INDIRECT_SOLVER delta regularization parameter polishing polishing boolean, polish ADMM solution polish_refine_iter iterative refinement steps polishing verbose boolean, write progress scaled_termination boolean, use scaled termination criteria check_termination integer, check termination interval. 0, termination checking disabled check_dualgap boolean, check duality gap termination criteria warm_starting boolean, warm start scaling heuristic data scaling iterations. 0, scaling disabled adaptive_rho integer, rho adaptation strategy: 0=disabled, 1=iterations, 2=time, 3=KKT error adaptive_rho_interval Number iterations rho adaptations rho. 0, automatic adaptive_rho_tolerance Tolerance X adapting rho. new rho X times larger 1/X times smaller current one trigger new factorization adaptive_rho_fraction Interval adapting rho (fraction setup time) cg_max_iter maximum number CG iterations (indirect solver ) cg_tol_reduction integer, number consecutive zero CG iterations tolerance gets halved (indirect solver ) cg_tol_fraction CG tolerance fraction (indirect solver ) cg_precond preconditioner CG method (indirect solver ): 0=none, 1=diagonal (Jacobi) profiler_level integer, level detail profiler annotations (0=) time_limit run time limit seconds (1e10 effectively disables) polish Deprecated. Use polishing instead. warm_start Deprecated. Use warm_starting instead.
